studyAmendmentImpacts.affectedSection: Synopsis; Section 3.1; Section 10.1; Section 11.2; Section 11.3; Section 17.9.1
studyAmendmentImpacts.description: Defined clinical cut-off for final CSR analysis, transition to long-term survival follow-up, and final OS analysis timing.
Clarified permitted and prohibited vaccinations, specifically restricting live-attenuated vaccines.
Introduced Subcutaneous (SC) administration of daratumumab as an alternative to IV during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Added monitoring and management requirements for Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) reactivation.

studyAmendmentReasons.reasonText: To define the clinical cut-off for the final CSR analysis and revise the end of study definition.
To provide flexibility for study investigators to prioritize patient safety during the global COVID-19 pandemic.
In response to identification of a new important risk (hepatitis B virus [HBV] reactivation).
Following review of data from the second interim analysis by the IDMC, allowing Arm A subjects access to daratumumab.

studyChanges.summary: Updated terminology to distinguish between final OS analysis and end of study.

studyChanges.afterText: Second primary malignancies added to medically important events.
studyChanges.summary: Expanded definition of medically important serious adverse events.
Added new section for subcutaneous administration procedures.
Removed severity definitions to rely solely on NCI-CTCAE Version 4.03.

studyChanges.afterText: Subjects whose dose was delayed for more than 4 weeks (Cycle 1 to Cycle 6) or more than 6 weeks (Cycle 7 and beyond) should have study treatment discontinued
studyChanges.summary: Clarified specific timeframes for treatment discontinuation due to dose delays.
